awd_titl_txt: Dissipation and Kinetic Physics of Astrophysical Turbulence
awd_abstract_narration:
Turbulence is one of the fundamental physical phenomena associated with fluids, gasses, and plasmas.  In astrophysical phenomena, turbulence provides a mechanism of efficient energy, momentum, and particle transport thus playing a key role in the dynamics of astrophysical objects. The solar wind has served as a unique laboratory for studies of turbulence due to the availability of measurements from spacecraft.   Accordingly, considerable effort has been made to study solar wind turbulence using a combination of observational, theoretical, and computational tools. While understanding of the basic physics of this phenomenon has advanced greatly, a significant number of key questions remain unanswered. This project proposes to use the Blue Waters leadership class computing system to execute ground-breaking large scale simulations to investigate how energy cascades and is ultimately dissipated in the solar wind. This study will significantly advance the state of knowledge of turbulence and will represent a very important milestone in the efforts to perform realistic modeling of solar wind turbulence. Additionally, the project results will be of great interest to a wide community of researchers working on solar wind plasma, coronal plasma, and plasma astrophysics. Overall, this project is part of a larger stream of fundamental scientific research, which is central to the mission of the NSF.

One particularly challenging question, which is the focus of this proposal, is what happens to the energy that is cascaded to kinetic scales by magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) turbulence. This question is not only of basic plasma physics interest, but is also directly related to the very important problem of solar wind and solar corona heating that is crucial to understanding of the Sun-Earth interaction, but has so far eluded a conclusive solution.  This study will overcome many of the limitations of existing approaches and will provide complementary information covering effects and parameter regimes inaccessible to other techniques. The planned 3D simulations on Blue Waters will reach into the MHD scales while retaining kinetic effects and will provide a glimpse into many of the crucial questions posed by the research community.  Additionally, the simulations will enable detailed comparison with spacecraft observations and exploration of the role of competing processes that are simultaneously present in the simulations. The wealth of information in these simulations is akin to data collected from many spacecraft missions and warrants analysis from the community at large. As such, the simulation data resulting from the project will be made available to the community for analysis.

por.por_cntn:
Plasma turbulence plays a significant role in the dynamics of many systems, from laboratory fusion experiments to the Sun and astrophysical objects such as accretion disks. While parameters and some details differ between these systems, there is also a large degree of similarity. This makes understanding of plasma turbulence a grand challenge problem impacting many areas of research. This project seeks to advance understanding of one aspect of the larger problem, namely how the turbulence heats background plasma. Depending of the parameters, the energy of plasma turbulence may be transferred to thermal energy of different plasma constituents (e.g. electrons, protons, heavy ions), or even lead to acceleration of particles to very high energies. Understanding of these issues may help advance our knowledge the solar wind and the solar corona, among other systems.  

A major focus of this study was on the solar wind turbulence. This will ultimately contribute to studies of space weather, i.e. the behavior of the near-Earth space environment.  Space weather has a significant impact on our society: for example, extreme solar events may affect or damage the power grid and communication satellites. Understanding of the solar wind and its turbulence may help develop better models that can forecast space weather. Moreover, thanks to the measurements performed by spacecraft in the solar wind, it remains the best-studied example of large-scale plasma turbulence, making it also interesting from the perspective of basic research.

A unique feature of this project, which required petascale resources like Blue Waters, is its use of complex, computationally expensive simulations that utilize simulation codes capable of faithfully describing microscopic physical effects. This is important, since in plasma turbulence the very nature of physical processes governing dynamics changes with scales.

One of the studies conducted under this project analyzed mechanisms that lead to formation of so-called current sheets, which are narrow regions of space with highly sheared magnetic field naturally formed by turbulence.  Around current sheets, turbulent energy may be converted to heat in a particularly efficient way. A number of simulations was performed and directly compared against spacecraft observations. The results were in remarkable agreement, indicating that the chosen model can properly describe turbulence-generated current sheets and paving wave for many subsequent studies.

Another important direction of the project was analyzing turbulence in plasmas embedded in strong magnetic fields. Such situation is encountered for example in the solar corona. In 2018 NASA launched a spacecraft mission called Parker Solar Probe (PSP), a "NASA mission to touch the Sun". PSP will pass as close as 9.8 solar radii from the Sun's surface, providing measurements that are expected to revolutionize our understanding of the solar corona and the solar wind, and will eventually lead to better models of Space Weather. There exists an urgent need to develop models that describe plasma turbulence in the regimes to be encountered by PSP. Meanwhile, majority of prior investigations of small-scale processes in turbulence focused on solar wind as seen at Earth?s orbit, where majority of prior measurements were performed. Theory suggests that turbulence is strongly modified close to the Sun relative to what happens at Earth's orbit. State-of-the-art simulations were used to confirm existence of this new regime of plasma turbulence and to study its properties, including behavior of the current sheets.

While the primary focus of the project was on solar wind turbulence, some attention was also paid to exploring issues common to all systems, as well as to several specific examples of turbulence distinct from the solar wind. One study analyzed turbulence generated by so-called pickup ions at the outer edges of the solar system. Pickup ions (PUIs) are produced by interaction of the solar wind with neutral gas of interstellar origin. PUIs are borne with ring-like distribution of velocities, which theories connect to the famous IBEX ribbon, a narrow band in energetic neutral atom emission detected by IBEX spacecraft. However, theories rely on a critical assumption that the initial ring-like distribution remains unchanged over approximately 2 years. The simulations conducted in this project were able to independently verify this assumption from first principles.

Finally, another study conducted under this project explored the consequences of turbulence for global properties of the Earth?s magnetosphere. Simulations were used to study how the interaction between turbulence generated upstream from the Earth?s bow shock and the bow shock itself leads to an important class of transient phenomena on the dayside of the Earth magnetosphere, known as magnetosheath High-Speed Jets (HSJs). The simulations helped uncover previously poorly understood three-dimensional structure of the HSJs and provided important clues into the mechanisms leading to their formation.
